subject: Re: Test Dependencies
msgSnippet: ...  ... The problem is saving, then loading, then verifying that the loaded object is equal to what was saved (if I understand your reasoning correctly)
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Bryce Fischer" <bryce@b...> wrote:
<snip>

> Given that I have two methods of my class I need to test, SaveLicense
> and LoadLicense, should I write this as two separate tests or as a
> single test that incorporates both? To clarify, to load a license, I
> would need to have a saved license. The load license would then verify
> that the information that was saved was loaded correctly.

The problem is saving, then loading, then verifying that the loaded
object is equal to what was saved (if I understand your reasoning
correctly) just tests that they you can load what you saved. It
doesn't verify that the format is correct. Also, the two ate tied
together.

I advise a separate test for each ("advise" because you don't work for
me.. if you did, I'd "insist"). And don't use real files if you can
help it. Use a mocked file for each test. Save to a mock that knows
what *should* be saved, then verify that that is what was saved. Read
from a fake that will supply a serialized object in the correct
format, then verify that the loaded object is correct. If you're
using Java you can work work with streams and not worry about files at
all. If the output format is textual (i.e. not binary) you can simply
supply string streams in the test... Mocks can result in cleaner test
code, though.

Your milage may vary.

Dave
